title: @Meddler: I really don't think you guys should buff Ryze....not yet at least.
body:
I know his winrate is astonishly low (last I checked it was the lowest). I know people automatically assume this means he's weak or clearly something of a winrate like this suggests he's weak. I'm going to explain why this shouldn't be so heavily considered with reworked champions, so just hear me out guys.

With new champions, when they have extremely low winrates like this it's one of two things: a very complex kit that takes time to learn or is actually very undertuned. Yasuo and Gnar come to mind, having very low winrates upon release and people automatically assumed they were garbage (i was guilty of this with Gnar). It took people time to figure them out but in that time, people figured out playstyles and builds and suddenly, they're overpowrred as all hell because you legit just buffed an extremely strong champion that people hadn't figured out yet.

I know what you're thinking now: what in gods name does this have to do with reworked champions? Well, I'll explain. With reworked champions, in a sense, they're much like new champions because there's a lot of intrigue with them much the same way there is with newly released champions. I'd imagine there's just as much attention paid to a newly released reworked champion as there is with a brand new champion altogether. 

Here's where you have to consider reworked champions on a totally different scale. With new champions, there is no reference point. Sure, champion spotlights will included suggested runes, masteries and builds but be honest, how many times have those been dead wrong? Sure they sound good in theory and in the right circumstances those suggested build paths and runes work but this is league where circumstances or so ever changing that it's hard to assume something is law upon new release and that same logic applies to builds, runes and masteries. So while the suggested builds and such are reference points, they aren't very good ones or reliable - they are guesstimations more or less (and that's not to discredit the people who come up with these, it makes sense at the time). 

So with reworked champions, you have to consider this: why was the champion reworked in the first place? Typically, it's because the champion has gameplay that riot considers less than desirable and is either bad or stagnant enough that riot considers a small overhaul of their spells or transferring of power as a start. With reworked champions, you have the reference point of how they were once played and built and many people make the tragic mistake of trying to build them the same way as before the teworks (see Sion and how people kept trying to build him full AD). In many cases, this is flawed because typically these builds and play styles are a result of the gameplay riot was trying to remove or change in the first place. In Ryzes case, and this is speculation this isn't something I actually know, riot wanted to remove his power as a top lane bully with point and click harass early that scales into burst and DPS into late while still being insanely durable. This is why riot tries to remove FH from build path or at least make it w's purchase that wastes stats. This is why they made his Q a skill shot (which is what completely broke him in top lane and made him weaker in mid lane) so he'd be less of a lane bully top and now suddenly mid lane looks more attractive.  So while Roa and Tear are still core, there's so much that's changed that you have to consider a new build path past those two items, that alone takes a lot of time to figure out.

Then there's this: you have to consider his playstyle and how drastically it was changed. There's no hiding from it, old Ryze was one of the easiest champions in the game with very few decision points (Q off CD? Fire away). His only concerns as a top laner was being pretty squishy and avoiding ganks and when to use Rune prison for disengaging - that was the extent of his difficulty. That changed, oh man did that change in a big way. His passive changed, which is a huge decision point in managing in itself. His ult suddenly gives him more of a spike. His Q is a long range skillshot now as opposed to point and click. I could keep going on but you get the point: his playstyle ha drastically changed. In fact, it's changed so much that I think he's legit one of the hardest champions to play now. The increase in his skillcap is insane, I've never seen this kind of change in a champions play style in my time that also made them super hard to play (Sion was a huge overhaul but he didn't suddenly become super hard to play, just slightly more difficult). 

I can't stress this enough, this was such an enormous change on a champion who was previously extremely unhealthy and now yoh could argue he's much healthier but as I noted, much harder. So it was a necessary change. But the point is, I suspect he's actually pretty good, it's just going to take a long time for people to figure all of the above out, which is actually a pretty unprecedented change when you consider reworks in league history (I'm excluding beta here). Give it time, don't buff him now. I think he's much healthier so this isn't me saying this because I don't want Ryze in my games again, it's because I do believe he's strong and if you play this champion, the last thing you want is for riot to keep buffing him when he's actually strong and it turns out they push him way over the edge and they end up nerfing him so hard, he actually becomes weaker than he was perceived to be prior to the buffs in the first place. 

As for builds, hey, I'm really a fan of this:

{{champion:13}} {{item:3027}} {{item:3040}} {{item:3020}} {{item:3152}} {{item:3135}} {{item:3800}} 

Runes: MS quints, scaling health yellows, spell pen reds, MR blues (scaling/flat depending on match up)

Masteries: 21/9 (9/21 actually doesn't feel bad either).

Some other items that aren't bad: {{item:3065}} (good vs heavy AP teams)
{{item:3110}} (you waste the 20% CDR but the mana and armor is nice against heavy AD teams)
{{item:3025}} (you don't waste CDR but sheen is kind of meh on him, as is the IBG proc since you don't AA too much on Ryze outside of lane phase; it might be really good though, idk yet)

The build I provided though gives him everything he likes. Mana, HP, damage, pen and spell vamp, which I think he's become an extremely good spell vamp champion. RG is just so good with his ult for chasing targets down as well. WOTA gives him the 10% that caps him out in CDR and it's nice AP and spell vamp, again, that synergies with his ult. 

There's also a few other items like {{item:3157}}  and {{item:3285}} that could be built over RG and potentially WOTA (and you could get the remaining CDR from runes and masteries). I love spel vamp Ryze, so it's bias. I think getting 10% CDR from runes and masteries and building Ludens is hella good too.

But do you see what I mean guys? Look at all this shit he can build and the vastly different playstyle patterns he potentially has with these builds now. How can we determine that he needs buffs after such a short time of being reworked so heavily and expect anything good to come of it? Give it a few more patches, I'd say until 5.13 at the very least. I really do think new Ryze is good.

We're on the same page regarding major reworks, in that they introduce enough change that there's going to be a readjustment period and that means a champion's performance is going to drop for a while. For that reason we didn't look at making any Ryze changes in 5.9 - we wanted to give things a bit of time to settle down. Now that we've got a couple of weeks of play to assess however it's a good time to see where Ryze is up to and then make changes as appropriate. 

It is possible that he's in a good spot already, and that's something the folks working on him will be considering. Looking at how he's performed so far however, and how that change in performance over time compares to other champions that have started off performing poorly but become really effective when mastered, I suspect we'll make the call to put power into him sometime soon. As with any buff it's conceivable that'll take a balanced character and make them too strong, that needs to be weighed against the risk of leaving a champion significantly underpowered however, which is also a real cost to the game (particularly players of Ryze and other players on their team).

I'm generally of the opinion that you exaggerated his 'windows of strength and weaknesses' too much, and also maybe advertised them. He's really strong when his passive procs (I remember my first game after the rework came out I got a double kill when I got ganked because the jungler was at half) but he's really weak otherwise. It's also really obvious when his passive is about to proc, so you have a giant warning sign 'STAY AWAY'. Unlike the other champ with a system like that, Gnar, he has no way to force a fight when he's about to be powerful apart from flash (or 'run into them and hope they don't have a blink.')

I agree leaving champions too weak and as a result, hurting the experience of the Ryze players, isn't a good thing either. But I cannot stress enough how this rework is almost on the same magnitude of Sion's rework - I don't put anything up there because let's face it, reworked Sion was basically a new champion. I know there isn't exactly a manual on this and at the end of the day, buffing him and overtuning him is probably a much easier fix than leaving him in poor shape. But I really do believe there's a lot of strength in this new kit and the flexibility of his build path right down to his runes and masteries is insane. Given his skillcap increase, I think there is also a very good chance that Ryze keeps a lower winrate much the same way many extremely powerful champions have in the past (see pre silence removal Leblanc as an example). I'm just iffy is all and after all this is only opinion based on very little facts - I also have the benefit of not having to answer to anyone if he turns out to be extremely weak. I'm just expressing here I think he's strong and it could potentially take a long time to figure him out in general. But that's also why I kind of went over builds for him and runes and masteries, even if this thread becomes a discussion point for that alone, maybe it helps. Who knows. Thanks for the reply bossman.

I can kind of see where you're coming from with the Sion comparison, I think a minor difference is that Ryze still feels like old Ryze, which actually probably does a bit of a disservice to him. I've been a Nidalee player for a long time, and when she got her rework, she still felt and played pretty much the same, long range poke with some windows to all in with cougar form. With Ryze, his spells still feel pretty much the same, and in that case he's pretty different than the Sion rework, but you kind of have to approach him in a completely different way, just because of how his passive is such a fulcrum for his gameplay now. The increased skill floor is a bit deceptive in that sense, I think.

Yo don't just downvote and move on. If you disagree then post here. This has really good discussion potential.

Ryze is weak. You can hypothesize all you want, but all the numbers point to him being bad right now. His kit is not so complicated that it would take players 2 weeks to get used to. He has real issues that have nothing to do with players not being used to him. 

* Short range and no mobility means he needs to burn flash or ulti to engage or escape
* Short and telegraphed window of power means one stun or silence and he can't deliver his damage
* In any given situation either Q or E will be not good
* When you do get off your combo, it doesn't do enough damage to feel rewarding
* CDR on his ulti is wasted stat. Many items he wants to build have CDR on them and during his window of power CDR is basically useless.
* Mana costs force him out of lane before most of his top lane opponents
* One of the most easily kited champs in the game

I'm not saying he doesn't have his strengths, but they don't cone close to compensating for his weaknesses; and I'm not buying that suddenly people will "learn how to play him" and he'll be strong.

Look I get it, you're a Nasus main and don't want a champ around that can potentially poke you off your farm, just please stop pretending like you understand this champ or his strengths and weaknesses.

I agree that Riot should consider the delay it takes the playerbase to learn a champ before seeing the low winrate and deciding it needs buffs.

However, I don't think Ryze's problem is his build, it's his newfound reliance on a passive that can time out.  It adds a Gnar-like downside to Ryze where he doesn't benefit from any of Gnar's strengths.  I think if Riot just let Ryze hold onto his passive charges indefinitely, Ryze would be a ton better (maybe too good, idk).

I don't think Ryze's passive is his major downfall. It's actually interesting to work with. It's controllable, like Jax's Ult passive and Vlad's E. Yes, it's obvious to predict but I don't think that's his weakness right now. I think the problem with Ryze is his laning. Always has been always will be. Where he stands right now, his counterplay is easy, stand behind your minions, don't get hit by his Q, you see a couple of runes around him? Wait it out. The problem with that is his kill potential in lane overall feels low and frustrating. Old Ryze players went from "I'm going to kill ya," to "Let's see if I can do something here." Ryze's Q does not feel rewarding to hit. It's out of place and boring, underpowered kinda. If you hit it, cool you did some poke damage, one step closer to killing someone. On any champ this is fine, but this is Ryze, it's his collective spell output that makes him unique and powerful. With it being a skillshot, that can be negated by standing behind minions, it feels inconsistent to the rest of kit. You fire out spells that are single target point and click, you don't worry about that. It's taunting us of what the old Ryze used to be. What if Ryze's Q was a skillshot that can go through minions but still be dodged and single targeted? Xerath ultesque maybe? Where it stands now, his Q doesn't feel impactful as a main damage output in lane. 
Overall, I think this rework was headed in the right direction but feels sloppy. His mana shield feels more like a gimmick as a better chunk of his damage now comes from AP. It kinda states, "Hey remember Ryze likes to build mana." Sure it does add to his tankiness and has saved my ass more often then not but it feels like a cheap outlet to remind us of old Ryze. Same with his ult, built in CDR? Another cheap outlet to force us to build something other than Frozen heart. 
What I think should've been done is exploring his theme of being a rapid fire mana building mage. What if his damage output gets better every time he hits a spell? What if he didn't have to rely on CDR to rapidly fire out spells or at all for that matter?

HateDaddy is pulling out some quality threads.

I approve.

And happen to agree.

Another thing is rune prison is really unreliable with regard to distance and vision. I constantly start casting the spell, only for it to not go off due to them leaving range or entering a bush. Please make it apply at the start of the cast animation, or at least always go off if you start the cast. I'd also like if they made it a edge-to-edge targeting so that it matches his auto-attack range, currently I can often auto without being in spell range. Making it grant vision of the snared target would also help; I've had instances where I snare someone, only to be unable to continue my combo because I lost vision of them in the bush.

If he does need more power can we try to add it slowly? Like instead of his entire passive dropping of at once he losses a stack on his passive one at a time? It would be a slight buff and maybe what he needs for people to transition from old ryze to new ryze while feeling spammy, allowing him to reach his windows of strength more often but not reducing the minimum amount of time he is vulnerable. It also wouldn't be that much of a buff to keep his passive up around 3 or 4 stacks because he would need to use his mana during that time making him a walking time bomb until he is much more useless.

I've played well over 50 games with the new Ryze, mostly in the jungle. Overall, he seems pretty weak, even though I've had pretty good luck with him. There's a quality-of-life buff I feel he really needs. When he cast his q, he continues his previous order after the casting animation, but not on his w or e. Adding this to his w and e would make playing him effectively (Cast kite Cast kite Cast kite) MUCH easier. I hope this is an easy fix, and not something hard programmed in skill shots and not in targets spells. The life sentence to rune prison is pretty sweet and rewarding when executed right.

i feel like new Ryze is one of those champions who, in a balanced state, will always have a sub-50% win rate, or barely 50%. His passive is pretty tough to manage, and I imagine the vast majority of players never fully mastering it, save a few dedicated players.

That being said, the powers spike he gets with the passive plus proper combo usage is night and day, honestly really massive, and his kit without it isn't too terrible, he can still play safe with the long range Q and his W. If you know how to manage your cooldowns and have all of them up, you can pretty much fight at 2 stacks and up, I think.

The thing I struggle with (me being something of a meter stick for the average player) is managing my cooldowns and passive in conjunction with engages in order to really utilize it, and also just comboing with that 0.25 second limit between spells. It's probably easier if you max w second for the longer duration so you don't have to orb walk during your combo, but I've found myself canceling spells since I try to spam my spells too quickly. Basically my problem is that his passive is tough to manage, and even when you have it, it's somewhat difficult to utilize since your casts need to be well timed and very cleanly executed, not to mention he's still short ranged.

I guess the distinction is, is he strong? Absolutely, he can be very strong, his passive proc is a massive power spike, and he's not totally helpless without it. But is he *good*? I guess it's kind of like asking if champions like Gnar, LeBlanc, Azir, Zed, etc are good. Sure they're powerful, many would say overwhelmingly so, but that power is largely inaccessible to much of the player base, because of differences in skill level of the players. For the average player, these champions aren't good, and statistically will lose them more games, even if they are powerful. It's kind of that age old question of who Riot should balance for, pros or your average player, and I'm on the side of the former, which is why I think Ryze won't, or shouldn't, have a win rate higher than 50%.

I think if Ryze receives any changes going forward, it should focus on usability instead of number buffs, since it isn't that he's weak per se, just his power is pretty difficult to access for the majority of players.

New Ryze feels overall fine. I'm really happy with the rework.

I feel like he has two real issues currently though. Mostly relating to his window of opportunity.

Basically, he's got two steroids that he relies on to do more than lightly poke. His passive and his Ult, the problem is that the duration is so short, especially at low levels. The duration could very much use a slight uptuning across all levels (but especially pre level 11). As it is, any CC at all and you're out of the fight until you can proc your passive again.

The second issue is with his passive exclusively, and it's more thorough for his playstyle.

Ryze's playstyle has always been about constantly spamming spells to charge his tear, the faster you fill your tear the faster you hit your real game.

Ryze's new passive now punishes you for not pacing yourself very carefully so that you'll only trigger the last hit when you really can go in on your opponent. So one of Ryze's core items directly drive him against managing his passive properly.

The other problem with how his passive stacks up is with how predictable it is, if you can't go in on the fifth hit, then you lose out on all your stacks for another cycle. The passive is painful to manage because you have to keep casting spells... but not too much, except for when you need to go all in faster than the opponent can get out of W range.

What Ryze really needs, is for his stacks to decay dynamically, one at a time, rather than all at once. That way you're rewarded for pacing yourself over an extended period of time, without the enemy being rewarded with their own windows of opportunity by the very nature of your kit.
